channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: Nvidia 主导着人工智能芯片制造。任何希望取代这家半导体巨头的竞争对手都需要在三大领域击败它。请阅读这将是一项艰巨任务的原因： 👇
item.description:
Nvidia dominates AI chipmaking. Any competitor hoping to displace the semiconductor behemoth will need to beat it in three big areas.

Read why that will be a tall order: https://t.co/7QXRWcBlXi 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 四分之三的年轻选民不赞成乔-拜登对加沙问题的处理。这对他的连任竞选意味着什么？
item.description:
Three-quarters of young voters disapprove of Joe Biden’s handling of Gaza. What does that mean for his re-election campaign? https://t.co/iggrCJ3WUn pic.twitter.com/0chxVnVxHn

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: Mistral 成立不到一年，目前仍只有 25 名员工。然而，这家法国人工智能初创公司的估值却超过了 20 亿美元。其早期成功的背后是什么？ 👇
item.description:
Mistral was founded less than a year ago and still has just 25 employees. Yet the French AI startup is valued at more than $2bn. What’s behind its early success? https://t.co/iGCAImQTDR 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 我们的互动工具可让您探索英国选民中的 900,000 个群体，这些群体是根据八个人口特征定义的。使用分享按钮展示您的作品 #BuildABritishVoter 🇬🇧
item.description:
Our interactive tool allows you to explore 900,000 groups within Britain’s electorate, defined according to eight demographic characteristics.

What does your voter look like? Use the share button to show off your creation https://t.co/kZVca5LTTc #BuildABritishVoter 🇬🇧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 英国穆斯林对工党的支持正在动摇。但在下次大选中，这种支持率下降的后果将是有限的，原因有两个 👇
item.description:
British Muslims’ support for Labour is wobbling. But the consequences of this decline in support at the next general election would be limited for two reasons https://t.co/DXS3FTKmn6 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 科学家们希望通过治疗导致 "接吻病 "的 Epstein-Barr 病毒来解决多发性硬化症问题。疫苗和抗病毒药物已在试验中 👇。
item.description:
Scientists want to tackle multiple sclerosis by treating the Epstein-Barr virus that causes “kissing disease”. Vaccines and antivirals are already undergoing trials https://t.co/NKKOcVGB6n 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 在英国上次大选中，工党遭遇了近一个世纪以来最惨痛的失败。是什么改变了工党？部分原因在于选民： 📈
item.description:
At Britain’s last general election Labour suffered its worst defeat in almost a century. Now the party is on the brink of entering office.

What changed? In part, the electorate did: https://t.co/P7jlW2DeJY 📈

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 乍一看，俄罗斯的经济欣欣向荣：商店里名牌商品琳琅满目，狂欢者在热闹的舞池中尽情狂欢。但在幕后，一切并不那么光明👇。
item.description:
At first glance Russia’s economy is thriving: shops bristle with designer goods and revellers party on heaving dancefloors. But behind the scenes things aren’t so bright https://t.co/Yv0WPYS9BL 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 是时候投资马尔贝克了吗？阿根廷企业主如何评估哈维尔-米莱 👇
item.description:
Is it time to invest in a spot of Malbec? How Argentine business-owners size up Javier Milei https://t.co/SuCV1FZXBk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 在阿列克谢-纳瓦尔尼逝世后，我们具有里程碑意义的播客系列 "莫斯科的下一年 "再次回归，调查战争在俄罗斯国内造成的破坏。与 @ArkadyOstrovsky 🎧 合作
item.description:
After the death of Alexei Navalny, our landmark podcast series, “Next Year in Moscow” returns to survey the damage war has wrought within Russia. With @ArkadyOstrovsky https://t.co/ZS5OR94vJv 🎧

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 对罗伯特-巴丹泰来说，仇恨从未像戴着正义面具时那样可怕。我们缅怀这位成功争取在法国废除死刑的律师和司法部长👇。
item.description:
For Robert Badinter, hatred was never so frightening as when it wore the mask of justice. And he had always mistrusted the mob.

We remember the lawyer and justice minister who successfully fought to abolish the death penalty in France https://t.co/dRiZxpq1Ty 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 现在，大多数老板都满足于关注股东回报，而不是努力改善整个社会。不过，尽管首席执行官们大多放弃了对利益相关者资本主义的调侃，但他们仍在承受其后果👇。
item.description:
Most bosses are now content to focus on shareholder returns, rather than trying to improve society at large. But although chief executives have mostly abandoned their flirtation with stakeholder capitalism, they are still living with its consequences https://t.co/e4hBOkCzcf 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 埃弗顿在英超联赛中违反了财务规定，因此陷入困境。该俱乐部的故事与英格兰足坛熟悉的模式如出一辙 ⚽。
item.description:
Everton has found itself in hot water after a breach of financial rules in the Premier League. The club’s story follows a familiar pattern in English football https://t.co/rufUMstlNK ⚽

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: "西方必须明白，政治犯是其在俄罗斯境内的主要盟友，"@纳坦-沙兰斯基在一篇特邀文章中指出，"西方与其对政治犯的命运表示'关切'，不如制定更加强硬的策略来确保他们的自由。
item.description:
“The West must understand that political prisoners are its main allies inside Russia,” argues @NatanSharansky in a guest essay.

Rather than express “concern” for their fate, he believes it must develop much harder tactics to ensure their freedom https://t.co/re4hXeyPht

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 您是否生活在世界上最昂贵的城市？ 👇
item.description:
Do you live in the world’s most expensive city? https://t.co/vsHGdcAXnw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 长期以来一直为伦敦的全球声誉和旅游收入做出贡献的伟大机构正在被短视所削弱。下一届工党政府会更加重视文化吗？ 👇
item.description:
Great institutions that have long contributed to London’s global prestige and tourism revenue are being weakened by short­-sightedness. Will the next Labour government take culture more seriously? https://t.co/vkLBRLyeWC 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 埃塞俄比亚曾经是非洲的 "亚洲虎"，但现在正走在一条不确定的道路上。这个经常被视为非洲大陆其他国家楷模的国家可能反而是一个警示👇。
item.description:
Ethiopia, once Africa’s “Asian tiger”, is on an uncertain path. A country often seen as a model for the rest of the continent may instead be a warning https://t.co/QQv1b2zfls 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 美国正在努力控制芬太尼。无论政府如何热心地在边境巡逻，如何凶猛地追捕毒贩，问题似乎只会越来越严重。美国需要新的策略来战胜它 👇。
item.description:
America is struggling to control fentanyl. No matter how zealously the government patrols the border and how ferociously it pursues traffickers, the problem only seems to get worse. The country needs new tactics to defeat it https://t.co/vnxu0pYtoE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 伊朗曾经是神权与民主的混合体，如今正蜕变成一个基础摇摇欲坠的绝对独裁政权。神职人员的统治还能继续吗？ 👇
item.description:
Once a hybrid theocracy-cum-democracy, Iran is morphing into an absolute dictatorship with a wobbly base. Will the clerics’ rule survive? https://t.co/EAmbtS6Vis 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 自俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，针对其广泛使用的资产冻结，通常被允许作为国际法下针对非法行为的反措施。然而，资产没收--至少在大多数解释中--并不允许。
item.description:
Asset freezes, which have been widely used against Russia since its invasion of Ukraine, are generally permitted as countermeasures to unlawful behaviour under international law.

Asset confiscations, however, are not—at least in most interpretations https://t.co/Jv1F47dH6A 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 西方跨国公司必须兼顾对俄罗斯员工和该国平民福祉的责任、对股东的责任以及资助弗拉基米尔-普京的乌克兰战争的不可取性 👇
item.description:
Western multinationals must juggle responsibility for their Russian employees and the well-being of the country’s civilians with their duty to shareholders and the undesirability of funding Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine https://t.co/jmgidXK04b 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 在音乐流媒体服务的世界里，几乎任何歌曲都只需点击几下即可获取。然而，人们仍然挤满了汗流浃背的地下室和泥泞的田野，聆听他们喜爱的音乐家的演奏。神经科学可以帮助解释为什么演出仍在继续👇。
item.description:
In a world of music streaming services, access to almost any song is just a few clicks away. Yet people still fill sweaty basements and muddy fields to hear their favourite musicians play.

Neuroscience can help explain why the gig lives on https://t.co/GjTrGxakeu 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 当世界变得越来越浮躁和科技化的时候，大自然中蕴含的传统却让人怀念。阅读 "柳条人 "为何能在今天引起共鸣 👇
item.description:
As the world becomes ever more frenetic and technological, there is a nostalgic appeal to traditions which are embedded in nature. Read why “The Wicker Man” seems so resonant today https://t.co/ZatKssVPaO 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 要想让更多的企业将采用人工智能技术视为不费吹灰之力的事情，就必须改进技术。迄今为止，最近的人工智能错误只让企业感到尴尬，但很容易想象会发生更糟糕的事情👇。
item.description:
For more businesses to see generative AI adoption as an open-and-shut case the technology needs to improve. Recent AI mistakes have so far only proved embarrassing for firms, but it is easy to imagine something much worse happening https://t.co/GBblNp74m8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 欧洲最昂贵的城市也是世界上最昂贵的城市，与新加坡并列 👇
item.description:
The most expensive city in Europe is also the most expensive in the world—tied with Singapore https://t.co/sGEEJwTZmN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 对个人和组织来说，总是生气都不是好事。但总是非常满意也是如此。更平和的员工应该学会偶尔发发脾气👇。
item.description:
Being angry all the time is bad news for individuals and organisations alike. But so is always being tremendously satisfied. More equable workers should learn to let their tempers fly occasionally https://t.co/G4crQLemQe 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 英国有数十万个 "幽灵池塘"。了解如何让它们起死回生：
item.description:
Britain is haunted by hundreds of thousands of “ghost ponds”. Find out how they can be summoned back to life: https://t.co/ejBxR7kOIQ pic.twitter.com/IKLl6xffga

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: "从长远来看，在这种制裁压力下的经济并不健康"@JCZarate1 在我们的 "Money Talks "播客中评估了西方对俄罗斯的金融战争👇。
item.description:
“Long term, this is not healthy for an economy under this kind of sanctions pressure.” @JCZarate1 assesses the West’s financial war on Russia, on our “Money Talks” podcast https://t.co/XppmFkHC6c 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: 虽然工党在英国穆斯林中仍保持着强有力的地位，但自加沙战争爆发以来，工党似乎失去了大量支持。2023 年初，工党在穆斯林选民中的支持率高达 75% 左右，而现在只有 65% 左右的穆斯林选民支持工党👇。
item.description:
Although Labour retains a strong position among British Muslims, it appears to have lost a substantial amount of support since the outbreak of war in Gaza. From a high of around 75% in early 2023, around 65% of Muslim voters now support the party https://t.co/hcNOTwO3oY 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024

item.title: "阿肖卡-莫迪（Ashoka Mody）认为，"几十年来，印度政治已经破坏了国家的道德结构。这位学者在一篇客座文章中写道："政治家和官员们正在'推进他们自己的利益，而不是公共利益'。
item.description:
“For decades Indian politics has unravelled the country’s moral fabric,” argues Ashoka Mody.

Politicians and officials are “advancing their own interests rather than the public good”, the academic writes in a guest essay https://t.co/uB0dj3kucW

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 3, 2024
